Award.AwardTitle: Flow of colloids and emulsions: Microscopic details of rearrangements and stresses

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1336401
PI: Weeks

In this project, the PI and his lab group will study the flow of soft materials, in particular emulsions (oil droplets in water). The goal is to connect the microscopic details of the flowing emulsions to their macroscopic properties. The project has two thrusts: first, to study the shear of dense three-dimensional emulsions; and second, to investigate the flow properties of dense two-dimensional emulsions. The 3D samples will be viewed using confocal microscopy. For these 3D samples, the importance of polydispersity will be examined using samples with droplet sizes that vary by as much as an order of magnitude. Flow of these highly polydisperse samples is qualitatively distinct from less polydisperse cases, and the data from this project will be a foundation to understand jammed materials that are highly polydisperse. For the 2D samples, the oil droplets will be confined between two parallel glass plates, so that the droplets are deformed into round quasi-two-dimensional disks. From the outlines of the droplets and knowledge of their surface tension, forces between droplet pairs will be measured and related to the rearrangements as the droplets flow. These measurements enable testing of theories of flowing amorphous materials. Microfluidic techniques will be used to create the oil droplets, allowing careful control over droplet sizes, viscosities, and surface tension.

Soft jammed materials are common, and include colloidal pastes (such as toothpaste), gels (such as gelatin), foams (such as shaving cream), and emulsions (such as mayonnaise). In contrast to regular liquids like water, the flow properties of these materials are less well understood. For example, the flow of an emulsion composed of oil droplets in water must involve rearrangements of individual droplets; additionally, the droplets can be stretched and even break up, making the flow even more complicated. The projects funded by this award will use microscopes to take movies of flowing emulsions, to see how the oil droplets move and how these motions are related to the forces required to flow them. This will lead to better understanding of how to create emulsions with specific flow properties, and how to better process emulsions in industry. Additionally, Professor Weeks will conduct at least one field trip each year to his laboratory for groups of primary school students. These students will investigate the properties of "squishy" materials such as the oil-and-water emulsions used in this project. While such materials are common and safe, they are also counterintuitive and get students curious. For example, consider shaving cream, which can sit in a pile on a table, in contrast to a puddle of soapy water which must lie flat. Such materials challenge the ideas students have that materials only come as solids, liquids, or gases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Soft jammed materials are common, and include colloidal pastes (such as toothpaste), gels (such as gelatin), foams (such as shaving cream), and emulsions (such as mayonnaise).  In contrast to regular liquids like water, the flow properties of these materials are less well understood.  For example, the flow of an emulsion composed of oil droplets in water must involve rearrangements of individual droplets.  We used microscopy to take movies of flowing emulsions and characterized the rearranging droplet motions in several ways.

One major project studied a highly concentrated sample of oil droplets.  Because of surface tension, these droplets would like to be spherical.  However, when highly concentrated, the droplets press against one another and form flat interfaces where they touch.  We studied these concentrated samples as they were forced to flow through a small tube.  Our lab developed a technique which let us use microscopic observations of the flat interfaces to measure the forces the droplets exert on each other.  We then investigated how these forces change as the droplets in the sample rearrange during flow.  For example, the forces within the sample build up prior to a rearrangement and then the rearrangement causes those internal forces to decrease.  In particular, there was a theoretical prediction that when two touching droplets separate, the forces on nearby droplets should change in a certain way.  Our experiments verified this theoretical prediction.  In particular, the forces acting on a droplet can increase or decrease depending on where the droplet is relative to the two separating droplets.  We found one unexpected result as well.  When the droplet concentrations are smaller, and the droplets feel smaller forces overall, the forces nearly always decrease when two droplets separate.  That is, two separating droplets cause all nearby droplets to feel reduced forces.  We showed that this is because the network of touching droplets is more randomized at these lower concentrations, so the orderly change in forces that had been predicted was no longer likely to occur.

A second major project was in collaboration with Solomon Barkley and Kari Dalnoki-Veress of McMaster University, Ontario, Canada.  Working with them, we explored a new method to make emulsion droplets that is simpler than many previous methods.  The method uses a tiny glass needle which slowly injects oil droplets into water.  When the droplets are sufficiently big, surface tension forces cause them to pinch off and separate from the needle.  The process is relatively insensitive to how fast the oil is injected, and the droplets are all the same size (to within about one percent).  We did a careful study to show how the droplet size depends on the size of the injecting needle and the surface tension, matching a theoretical model we developed to explain the process.  This new method should be useful to a wide range of scientists who need to make droplets with good control over their size.  The simplicity of the method also makes it relatively inexpensive compared to many prior methods.

A third major project was a study of how droplets rearrange in highly concentrated emulsion samples that contain both really small and really large droplets.   Many scientists have studied samples where the largest droplets are only twice as big as the smallest droplets, and they found that rearrangements happen involving only small numbers of droplets that are adjacent.  We studied samples where the largest droplets are more than ten times larger than the smallest droplets.  We saw that the motion of the largest droplets cause many other droplets to rearrange, and the overall behavior is quite different from the previously studied samples.  Our experiments are relevant for industrially useful complex fluids (samples composed of particles or droplets mixed into another liquid) where often there is a wide range of sizes in the same sample.

Additionally, during the course of this grant period we conducted several field trips where first grade students visited our laboratory.  When the students visited, they did hands-on play with corn starch and water; they did their own experiments studying sand; and they filmed several interesting phenomena using our high-speed video camera (such as popping a balloon).  We also had one field trip of high school students who came to visit.

One undergraduate involved in this research is now in a Ph.D. physics program.  Ph.D. students involved in this research are now working elsewhere:  one works in industry, one is a postdoctoral fellow at another university, and one is a tenure-track physics professor (Aquinas College).
